LanguageReference.Name: store
LanguageReference.Title: store()
LanguageReference.p: The store() statement lets you store a string of characters or keys in a buffer for use elsewhere in the keyboard source file. The store() statement can be used with any() and index() to reduce sets of similar rules down to a single rule.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: name
LanguageReference.Title: &name
LanguageReference.p: The &name store lets you give a more descriptive name to your keyboard than just the file name. If &name isn't specified in the keyboard file, Keyman will use the filename of the keyboard, excluding the extension, so the &name statement is optional.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: version
LanguageReference.Title: &version
LanguageReference.p:
The &version store allows Keyman to distinguish what version of Keyman the keyboard was written for and handle it accordingly. The &version store is optional. For most keyboards, it should be omitted.
If the &version store is omitted, the compiler will infer the lowest version that supports the full set of features used in the keyboard, and assign that version number value to this store internally. The compiler will also report on the version it infers in the compile process.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: begin
LanguageReference.Title: begin rule
LanguageReference.p: The begin rule tells Keyman which groups should be entry points to the keyboard.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: use
LanguageReference.Title: use() statement
LanguageReference.p: The use() statement tells Keyman to switch processing to a new group; after Keyman has gone through the new group, and any other nested groups, it will return to the previous one. The use() statement can be used with the match and nomatch rules; it will work the same way.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: outs
LanguageReference.Title: outs()
LanguageReference.p: The outs() statement simply copies the store 'storeName' into the position in which it has been inserted. This can be used in stores, in the context and the output. If the store to be emitted is a single character or virtual key, it can also be used in the key part of the rule.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: any
LanguageReference.Title: any()
LanguageReference.p: The any() statement will match any character that is in the store 'inputStore'. This statement is only valid on the left side of a rule; the index() statement is used to match again or output the character matched by the any() statement in the output. The any() statement remembers the offset in the store where the match occurred for later use with the index() statement.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: index
LanguageReference.Title: index()
LanguageReference.p: The index() statement works together with any() to map an array of characters in 'inputStore' to a corresponding array in 'outputStore'. index() can be used in the context and output sections of a rule. If used in the context section, the offset parameter must be less than the offset of the index() statement in the context.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: group
LanguageReference.Title: group()
LanguageReference.p: The group() statement tells Keyman to start a new set of rules. Keyman supports three sorts of groups: key processing groups, read-only groups, and context processing groups.
Syntax
LanguageReference.div:
group(groupName)
group(groupName) using keys
group(groupName) readonly

LanguageReference.Name: context
LanguageReference.Title: context
LanguageReference.p: The context statement reproduces the context stored from the rule match, or a single character of it, into the output. Use the context statement as much as possible as it is significantly faster than using the index statement.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: beep
LanguageReference.Title: beep
LanguageReference.p: The beep statement produces a beep with the system speaker when the rule is matched. In Keyman Desktop, beep will produce the sound specified by "Asterisk" in Windows Sounds configuration.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: platform
LanguageReference.Title: platform() statement
LanguageReference.p: The platform() statement allows rules to match based on the device on which the Keyman keyboard is running.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: nul
LanguageReference.Title: nul
LanguageReference.p: The nul statement has two purposes: in the output of a rule, it signifies deleting context and keystroke, and at the start of the context it signifies that the context buffer in the application must be empty (or no longer than the context of the rule) in order for the rule to match.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: copyright
LanguageReference.Title: &copyright
LanguageReference.p: The &copyright store allows a keyboard author to embed a copyright statement in a keyboard when it is compiled.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: message
LanguageReference.Title: &message
LanguageReference.p: This is a generic message, such as a shareware notice that you can display when the keyboard is installed. This statement is optional.The MESSAGE statement is deprecated and the &message store should be used instead.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: targets
LanguageReference.Title: &targets
LanguageReference.p: The &targets store specifies the target platforms for which a keyboard should be built.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: layoutfile
LanguageReference.Title: &layoutfile
LanguageReference.p: The &layoutfile store specifies a touch layout .JSON file to incorporate in the Keyman keyboard. If a touch layout is not specified, then Keyman will build one from the visual keyboard description file referenced in the &visualkeyboard store. If neither is specified, then Keyman builds a touch layout based on the US English desktop keyboard layout.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: keyboardversion
LanguageReference.Title: &keyboardversion
LanguageReference.p: The &keyboardversion store documents the version of the keyboard. Keyman uses this on touch platforms to check for updated versions of the keyboard and update them automatically.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: bitmap
LanguageReference.Title: &bitmap
LanguageReference.p: The bitmap can be in two different formats: .bmp or .ico. A .bmp file must be a 16x16 image. Keyman supports .ico files with multiple image sizes, and the appropriate size will be used if available.
Syntax

LanguageReference.Name: visualkeyboard
LanguageReference.Title: &visualkeyboard
LanguageReference.p: The &visualkeyboard store specifies a .kvks file to reference in the compiled Keyman keyboard. The .kvks (XML format) is compiled into a .kvk binary On Screen Keyboard which needs to be distributed with the .kmx.
Syntax

Control.Name: editFilter
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The Filter allows a user to reduce the number of characters displayed in the character map. The standard filter options used are by font name or block name.

Control.Name: grid
Control.Title: Character Map
Control.p: The Character Map Grid displays each character in a square, with a visual representation of the character and the Unicode value displayed at the bottom of the square. Each font group is divided into a block headed by the font name.

Control.Name: cmdFilter
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The Filter allows a user to reduce the number of characters displayed in the character map. The standard filter options used are by font name or block name.

Control.Name: rbRange
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The filter format for a range is: [U+]XXXX-[U+]YYYY, where U+ is optional, XXXX is the starting Unicode value and YYYY is the finishing Unicode value.

Control.Name: editRangeStart
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The filter format for a range is: [U+]XXXX-[U+]YYYY, where U+ is optional, XXXX is the starting Unicode value and YYYY is the finishing Unicode value.

Control.Name: editRangeStop
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The filter format for a range is: [U+]XXXX-[U+]YYYY, where U+ is optional, XXXX is the starting Unicode value and YYYY is the finishing Unicode value.

Control.Name: rbName
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: The Filter allows a user to reduce the number of characters displayed in the character map. The standard filter options used are by font name or block name.

Control.Name: cmdCharactersInCurrentFontOnly
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: ">" placed at the start of an entry will only show characters in the currently selected Character Map font. This is helpful when trying to determine which characters a given font supports.
Example: >LAO
finds all characters with names starting in "LAO" in the current font

Control.Name: cmdBlock
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: "<" placed at the start of an entry will search Unicode block names instead of character names. This is helpful when searching for characters within related blocks
Example: <Thai
finds the Thai Unicode block

Control.Name: cmdStar
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Using "*" in an entry serves as a wildcard for any number of places in that entry. For example, searching for "greek*alpha" will find characters whose Unicode names begin with the word "Greek" and contain the word "Alpha" any number of places later. This is helpful when searching for characters that share a common element in their names (e.g. capital).

Control.Name: cmdQuestionMark
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Using "?" anywhere in an entry serves as a wildcard for that single place in the entry. For example, searching for "s???e" will return both the SPACE and the SMILE characters, among others.

Control.Name: cmdRange
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Example: 1000-119F
finds all characters between U+1000 and U+119F (inclusive) - the Myanmar alphabet in this case

Control.Name: cmdSet
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Example: LATIN * LETTER [AEIOU]
finds all all Latin A,E,I,O or U vowel combinations

Control.Name: cmdDollar
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: "$" placed at the end of an entry will match from the end of a Unicode character name. This option works best when used with "*" or "?".
Example: LATIN * LETTER A$
finds only "a" and "A"

Control.Name: cmdOK
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Click OK to save changes and close the dialog.

Control.Name: cmdCancel
Control.Title: Character Map Filter
Control.p: Click Cancel to close the dialog without saving changes.

Control.Name: editKeyboardVersion
Control.Title: Keyboard Version
Control.p: The Keyboard Version documents the version of the keyboard.

A keyboard version should be updated whenever there are changes to a keyboard. The good principles to follow are:
Increment the major version number for a keyboard that has significant new functionality.
Increment the minor version number for changes that impact functionality but not in a significant manner.
Optionally, use a third number for bug fixes.
This corresponds to the following source line:
Note: there is a difference between &keyboardversion, which documents the keyboard version, and &version, which determines which version of Keyman a keyboard will run with.

Control.Name: memoComments
Control.Title: Comments
Control.p: In this field, enter information about the keyboard for your own reference. These comments will only be visible in the source file, and not to users of your keyboard.
The comments are placed at the top of the source file, e.g.:
Control.div:
c Version 1.2 - fixed a bug with the 'k' key
c Version 1.1 - improved matching on vowels
c Version 1.0 - initial version

Control.p: This will open a selection dialog allowing you to choose a feature to add to the keyboard project. Adding a feature will add an extra tab to the editor, and add the corresponding store to the keyboard source

Control.Name: cmdEditFeature

Control.p: Depending on what is included in the Feature Grid, you can select a feature from the grid then click on Edit... This will take you to the corresponding tab and let you make changes.

Control.Name: cmdRemoveFeature

Control.Name: cmdImport
Control.Title: Import
Control.p: The import option allows for the loading of an existing icon from a selected location.

Control.Name: panEdit
Control.Title: Icon Editor
Control.p: The toolbox allows for the changing of the colours, addition of text and shapes. It also allows for the moving of the icon around the canvas and also a preview of the icon is displayed.

Control.Name: palColours
Control.Title: Colours
Control.p: Click on a colour from the box to apply the colour onto the Keyboard's icon. You can see the Foreground Color displays the colour you chose. To deselect the colour, click on the X mark on the corner left of the colour box, or choose another colour.

Control.Name: pages
Control.Title: Pages
Control.p: This tab allows you to edit the visual representation of your keyboard layout. The content on this tab is stored in the .kvks file associated with your keyboard. The visual representation is used only in desktop and desktop web; however if no touch layout is defined, this layout will be synthesized into a touch layout automatically.

An On-Screen keyboard is optional but in most keyboards is recommended. The On-Screen keyboard may not always match the actual layout identically, because you may choose to hide some of the details of encoding from the interface presented to the user.
This keyboard layout can also be printed or included in HTML or other documentation. The editor allows you to export the file to HTML, PNG or BMP formats.

Control.Name: chkFillUnderlyingLayout
Control.Title: Auto-fill underlying layout
Control.p: If this option is checked, when the Fill from layout button is clicked, then keys without corresponding rules in the Layout will be filled with the base layout character.

Control.Name: chkCustomOnScreenKeyboard
Control.Title: Include
Control.p: A custom on screen (visual) keyboard can be included with your new keyboard. Check this option to display the on screen keyboard and options available.

Control.Name: chkLayoutDisplay102key
Control.Title: European Keyboards
Control.p: On European Keyboards a 102nd key is added. This allows you to map a character on the 102nd key.

Control.Name: chkIncludeTaskbarIcon

Control.p: This option allows the user to choose whether the keyboard icon is displayed on the taskbar and to customise the look of the icon. Check the Include Icon on the Taskbar to display the icon bitmap editor.

Control.Name: chkSplitCtrlAlt

Control.Name: cmdAddToProject

Control.Name: cmdInsertCopyright

You can test within the web browser on your device, or in the native app if you have it installed: just click the Install button on the debugger web page.

Control.Name: editStartMenuDescription
Control.Title: Start
Control.p: The text to be displayed for the selected file as a menu item in the Start up folder that is created when the package is installed.

Control.Name: cmdStartTestOnline
Control.Title: Test package on web
Control.p: Starts the Keyman Developer Web Server for the keyboard package. This will list the various IP addresses and hostnames that Keyman Developer is listening on.

Control.Name: lbDebugHosts
Control.Title: Web addresses
Control.p: A list of available servers to test the keyboard package.

Control.Name: cmdOpenDebugHost
Control.Title: Open in browser
Control.p: Starts your default browser with the selected address to allow testing of the keyboard package directly.

Control.Name: editBootstrapMSI
Control.Title: Keyman MSI
Control.p: Specifies the location of the Keyman MSI file. As of Keyman Developer 17, bundled executable package installers for Keyman for Windows can be created using kmc, but cannot be created within the IDE.

Control.Name: cbImageFile
Control.Title: Image File
Control.p: You can include an image file that will be displayed to the left of the install details when the package is installed. This image should be 140 pixels wide and 250 pixels high.

Control.Name: cbReadmeFile
Control.Title: Readme file
Control.p: The readme file can be displayed after the installation of the keyboard package, but can also be accessed from the keyboard folder at a later time. The file must be loaded under the Files tab, add option before being able to be selected from the drop down list.

Control.Name: cmdAddFile
Control.Title: Add Files
Control.p: This option allows the user to add new files to the package.

Control.Name: cmdInsertCopyright
Control.Title: Insert Copyright
Control.p: This allows for the insertion of a copyright symbol if needed.

Control.Name: cbReadMe
Control.Title: Read Me Details
Control.p: A readme file can be a text file (ANSI, UTF-8, or UTF-16), or an HTML file (recommended). Other file types are also acceptable, but the package installer will load the file in a separate program.

Control.Name: cbKMPImageFile
Control.Title: Package Image
Control.p: You can include an image file that will be displayed to the left of the install details when the package is installed. This image should be 140 pixels wide and 250 pixels high.

Control.Name: cmdTestPackage
Control.Title: Test Package
Control.p: You should try installing your package on your system before distributing it, to ensure that all files are installed correctly. If you can, try installing your package on several different machines.

Control.Name: editOutPath
Control.Title: Compile
Control.p: Displays the output path and filename of the file when the package is compiled.

Control.Name: cmdCompileInstaller
Control.Title: Compile Installer
Control.p: Creates a self-extracting installer consisting of the package plus Keyman or another Keyman Engine product that was created with the Branding Pack.

Control.Name: editInstallerOutputFilename
Control.Title: Installer Output Filename
Control.p: Displays the output filename and path for the self-extract installer.

Control.Name: cmdInstallWith
Control.Title: Select Product Installer
Control.p: Chooses a product installer, such as the Keyman installation source. You can download Keyman installers from keyman.com.

Control.Name: cmdAddToProject
Control.Title: Add to Project
Control.p: This option allows the user to add the compile package to the project, keeping all files together in the one location.

Control.Name: cmdBuildPackage
Control.Title: Compile Package
Control.p: This option checks the package has all the required files and for any errors. The success of the compilation is displayed at the bottom of the screen.

Control.Name: cmdInstall
Control.Title: Install Package
Control.p: This option will install the package on the computer. A message will be displayed as to the success of the install.

Control.Name: cmdOpenContainingFolder
Control.Title: Open Containing Folder
Control.p: Opens the source folder of the selected file.

Control.Name: cmdOpenContainingFolder2
Control.Title: Open Containing Folder
Control.p: This option will open the folder the selected package is located in.

Control.Name: cmdOpenFile
Control.Title: Edit
Control.p: This option allows the user to edit the selected file if the appropriate editor is available.

Control.Name: cmdRemoveFile
Control.Title: Remove Files
Control.p: This option allows the user to remove a selected file from the list.

Control.Name: cmdUninstall
Control.Title: Uninstall Package
Control.p: This option will uninstall the package from the computer. A message will be displayed as to the success of the uninstall.

Control.Name: cmdUpload
Control.Title: Upload
Control.p: This option will enable the developer to upload the package to the Tavultesoft website.

Control.Name: editFilePath
Control.Title: Path
Control.p: Displays the location of the selected file.

Control.Name: editFileType
Control.p: File Type
Enter the details of the file type being added to the keyboard package.

Control.Name: lbFiles
Control.Title: Package Files
Control.p: This will display all the files that have been added to the keyboard package. It allows for the addition and removal of files, the entering of file details and the editing of any of the files listed if the appropriate editor is available.

Control.Name: memoFileDetails
Control.Title: Details
Control.p: This option allows the user to enter details and other additional information about the selected file.

Control.Title: Project Manager
Control.p: The Project Manager allows you to manage all the files related to a keyboard layout in a single location.

Control.Name: editAuthor
Control.Title: Author Name
Control.p: The name of the developer of the keyboard. This is either your full name or the organization you're creating a model for.

Control.Name: editModelName
Control.Title: Model Name
Control.p: We recommend the name of the language, dialect, or community that this model is intended for. The name must be written in all the Latin letters or Arabic numerals.

Control.Name: editCopyright
Control.Title: Copyright
Control.p: Who owns the rights to this model and its data? Typically, you can use the automatically generated default value: © 2024 Your Full Name or Your Organization.

Control.Name: editVersion
Control.Title: Version
Control.p: If this is the first time you've created a lexical model for you language, you should leave the version as 1.0. Otherwise, your version number must conform to the following rules: A version string made of major revision number.minor revision number.

Control.Name: gridLanguages
Control.Title: Languages
Control.p: Specifies the default BCP 47 language tags which will be added to the package metadata and project metadata.

Control.Name: cmdAddLanguage
Control.Title: Add...
Control.p: To add a language tag, click the Add button to bring up the “Select BCP 47 Tag” dialog box.

Control.Name: cmdEditLanguage
Control.Title: Edit...
Control.p: Click the Edit button to bring up the “Select BCP 47 Tag” dialog box again and edit the language tag.

Control.Name: cmdRemoveLanguage
Control.Title: Remove
Control.p: Click the Remove button to delete the language tag.

Control.Name: editPath
Control.Title: Path
Control.p: Specifies the base path where the project folder will be created.

Control.Name: cmdBrowse
Control.Title: Browse...
Control.p: Browse for a folder or create a new folder to save the project to.

Control.Name: editAuthorID
Control.Title: Author ID
Control.p: An Author ID is a unique identifier used to distinguish you from others who have the same or similar names.

Control.Name: cbBCP47
Control.Title: Primary Language
Control.p: Choose your primary language which generated from the “Select BCP 47 Tag” dialog box.

Control.Name: editUniq
Control.Title: Unique Name
Control.p: Enter a unique name of the model. You can use the name of the language, dialect, or community that this model is intended for.

Control.Name: editModelID
Control.Title: Model ID
Control.p: Keyman automatically generates a model ID for you, given all the information already filled out. Model ID helps Keyman sorts and organizes different lexical models.

Control.Name: editProjectFilename
Control.Title: Project filename
Control.p: Specifies the base path where the project filename (.model.kpj) will be created.

Control.Name: memoDescription
Control.Title: Description
Control.p: Enter information about the model.

Control.Name: cmdCancel
Control.Title: Cancel
Control.p: Click Cancel to close the dialog without saving changes.

Control.Name: pages
Control.Title: Wordlist tabs
Control.p: Wordlist tabs have two views: Design, and Code. Changes to one view are reflected immedaitely in the other view. Wordlist files should be stored in UTF-8 encoding (preferably without BOM), and tab-separated format.

Control.Name: gridWordlist
Control.Title: Wordlist tabs
Control.p: Every line of the tab-separated format file is shown here, and can be edited directly. For most wordlists, it will be more effective to use an external dictionary tool, such as SIL Fieldworks or SIL PrimerPrep to generate the wordlist from a text corpus, and use this tab just to preview the contents of the file.

Control.Name: cmdDeleteRow
Control.Title: Wordlist tabs
Control.p: The Delete row button will delete the selected row in the wordlist.

Control.Name: cmdSortByFrequency
Control.Title: Wordlist tabs
Control.p: The Sort by frequency button has no effect on the functioning of the wordlist, but can help you, the editor, by showing more common words earlier in the list.

Control.Name: cefwp
Control.Title: Editor Window
Control.p: Editor windows in Keyman Developer supports standard Windows editing keystrokes. Many file formats, including .kmn, .kps, .xml, .html, .js and .json, support syntax highlighting. The text editor in Keyman uses the Monaco component from Visual Studio Code, so all the functionality available in that editor is also available here.

Control.Name: gridFonts
Control.Title: Character Identifier
Control.p: Attempt to identify the fonts on your system that will support the characters. You can quickly change fonts by clicking on a font name in the grid of identified fonts.

Control.Name: sgChars
Control.Title: Character Identifier
Control.p: Display the Unicode value of the selected character.

Control.Name: memoMessage
Control.Title: Message Window
Control.p: The message window appears at the bottom of the screen, or floating in a toolbar window. It contains a list of error and warning messages returned from a compilation session. You can undock and dock the window by dragging its title bar.

Control.Name: memo
Control.Title: Debugger input window
Control.p: The debugger input window is used for typing input to test the keyboard. In the top half of this window, input you type while testing your keyboard will be displayed, exactly the same as in use, with one exception: deadkeys will be shown visually with an OBJ symbol.

Control.Name: sgChars
Control.Title: Debugger input window
Control.p: The lower half of the window shows a grid of the characters to the virtual left of the insertion point, or the selected characters if you make a selection. Deadkeys will be identified in the grid. The grid will show characters in right-to-left scripts in backing store order, from left to right. If there are more characters in your text than can fit on the screen, then only those that fit will be shown in the grid.

Control.Name: lbRegTestLog
Control.Title: Regression Testing
Control.p: The idea in regression testing is to record a sequence of keystrokes and the output the keyboard produced, in order to test for the same behaviour when you make changes to the keyboard.

Control.Name: cmdRegTestStartStopLog
Control.Title: Regression Testing
Control.p: Use Start Log/Stop Log to record the input and output. You can then use Start Test to run the test again, or go the Options menu to clear the log, or save or load a test, or use the batch mode to run several tests in a row.
If the output produced while running a test is different to that stored when recording it, Keyman will halt the test on the line where the failure occurred, and activate Single Step mode.

Control.Name: cmdRegTestOptions
Control.Title: Regression Testing
Control.p: In the Options menu, you can clear the log, save or load a test, or use the batch mode to run several tests in a row.

Control.Name: cmdRestartDebugger
Control.Title: State
Control.p: Pressing the Restart button will clear the keystroke log as well as clearing the text in the debug window.

Control.Name: lbKeystrokeLog
Control.Title: State
Control.p: This window shows the current keystroke state, and the sequence of keystrokes that were typed to arrive at this state.

Control.Name: lvElements
Control.Title: Elements
Control.p: This shows the elements that make up rule currently being processed: the context, the key, and also what the output will be. If the rule uses stores, the contents of the store will be shown in the right-hand column, with the matched letter in red.

Control.Name: lbCallStack
Control.Title: Call Stack
Control.p: Here all the lines that have been processed to this point are shown in a list. You can double-click on any entry in the list to display the line in the keyboard source.

Control.Name: lbDeadkeys
Control.Title: Deadkeys
Control.p: This lists all the deadkeys that are currently in the context. You can select one from the list to see it highlighted in the debug input box. This information can also be seen in the character grid in the lower half of the debugger input window.

Control.Name: cmdOK
Control.Title: About Dialog
Control.p: The About dialog displays copyright and registration information for Keyman Developer, and has a link to the Keyman website.

Control.Name: cmdInsert
Control.Title: Virtual Key Identifier
Control.p: This dialog lets you check the virtual key code for any key combination (except Window reserved key combinations such as Alt + Tab). You can then insert the virtual key code into the last active edit window at the current cursor position.
Press Shift + Enter to insert the current virtual key code into your source at the insertion point.

Control.Name: chkLRDistinguish
Control.Title: Virtual Key Identifier
Control.p: You can see the virtual key codes for left and right Ctrl / Alt combinations by checking the "Distinguish between left and right ctrl/alt" checkbox.

Control.Name: cmdClose
Control.Title: Virtual Key Identifier
Control.p: To close the dialog, click the Close button or press Shift + Esc.

Control.Name: cbLanguageTag
Control.Title: Language tag
Control.p: The only required option is the Language tag, which is an ISO 639-1 or ISO 639-3 code. ISO 639-1 tags are a two-letter code. ISO 639-3 tags are a three-letter code. First, try to find your language on the list of two-letter ISO 639-1 codes.
If you can't find a two-letter code, you'll need to find the closest three-letter code. You can use Glottolog to search for your language, and it will give you an appropriate code.
The Language tag is conventionally written in lower case.

Control.Name: cbScriptTag
Control.Title: Script tag
Control.p: The Script tag allows you to specify the writing system used in your language model or keyboard. If your language only uses one writing system, omit the Script subtag. he Script subtag is conventionally written in title case - first letter capitalized.

Control.Name: cbRegionTag
Control.Title: Region tag
Control.p: The Region tag allows you to specify the region your language or dialect is spoken in. If your language is only spoken in one region, omit the Region subtag. Alphabetic region will show up in upper case once the region tag is selected.

Control.Name: editBCP47Code
Control.Title: BCP 47 Code
Control.p: This is the BCP 47 Code forms from the language, script, and region tag which were previously selected.

Control.Name: editLanguageName
Control.Title: Language name
Control.p: If lefts as default, a language name will be assigned automatically. Feel free to change the name if you must.

Control.Name: cmdResetLanguageName
Control.Title: Reset
Control.p: Reset the Language name to what it was assigned to.

Control.Name: cmdOK
Control.Title: OK
Control.p: Once everything is set, click OK to confirm.

Control.Name: cmdCancel
Control.Title: Cancel
Control.p: Exits out of the "Select BCP 47 Tag".

Control.Name: lblLinkToW3C
Control.Title: Learn about BCP 47 Tag
Control.p: Learn more about the BCP 47 Tag over at w3.org.

Control.Name: editKeyboardName
Control.Title: Keyboard name
Control.p: The descriptive name of the keyboard. This will be set in the &Name store in the keyboard, in the package name, and where appropriate in documentation and metadata.

Control.Name: memoDescription
Control.Title: Description
Control.p: A brief or long description about the keyboard's functionality, background, script, language, community, or any information related to showcase to users.

Control.Name: editAuthor
Control.Title: Author
Control.p: The name of the developer of the keyboard. This is either your full name or the organization you're creating the keyboard for.

Control.Name: editCopyright
Control.Title: Copyright
Control.p: This field should contain the word "Copyright", the copyright symbol "©", and the full name of the rights owner. Do not put the year of copyright in this field (see Full Copyright). Typically, you can use the automatically generated default value: "Copyright © Your Full Name or Your Organization".
A copyright string for the keyboard. This will be set in the &Copyright store in the keyboard, in the package metadata, and where appropriate in documentation and metadata.

Control.Name: editFullCopyright
Control.Title: Full Copyright
Control.p: Who owns the rights to this keyboard? This field should contain the word "Copyright", the copyright symbol "©", the first year of copyright, and the full name of the rights owner. Do include the year of copyright in this field. Typically, you can use the automatically generated default value: "Copyright © Current-Year Your-Full Name or Your Organization".

Control.Name: editVersion
Control.Title: Version
Control.p: If this is the first time you've created a keyboard for the language, you should leave the version as 1.0. Otherwise, your version number must conform to the following rules: A version string made of major revision number.minor revision number.

Control.Name: clbTargets
Control.Title: Targets
Control.p: Specifies the default deployment targets for the keyboard, set in the &Targets store in the keyboard, and controls the files added to the package initially. This also is reflected in documentation and metadata.

Control.Name: editPath
Control.Title: Edit Path
Control.p: Specifies the base path where the project folder will be created. The project folder name will be the keyboard ID. If the folder already exists, then you will be prompted before Keyman Developer overwrites files inside it.

Control.Name: cmdBrowse
Control.Title: Browse
Control.p: Specifies a different path to store the project folder.

Control.Name: editKeyboardID
Control.Title: Keyboard ID
Control.p: The base filename of the keyboard, project and package. This must conform to the Keyman keyboard identifier rules, using the characters a-z, 0-9 and _ (underscore) only.

Control.Name: editProjectFilename
Control.Title: Keyboard ID
Control.p: A Keyboard Project (.kpj) file is store inside the base path, this cannot be changed to anywhere else.

Control.Name: cmdKeyboardAddLanguage
Control.Title: Add a Language
Control.p: This button will open up the BCP 47 Tag window to add the keyboard's language tag, script tag, region tag, and language name.

Control.Name: cmdKeyboardEditLanguage
Control.Title: Edit a Language
Control.p: Click on Edit... to open up the BCP 47 Tag window with the language information.

Control.Name: cmdKeyboardRemoveLanguage
Control.Title: Remove a Language
Control.p: Delete the selected language.

Control.Name: cmdOK
Control.Title: OK
Control.p: Once everything is ready, click OK and enjoy developing the keyboard.

Control.Name: cmdCancel
Control.Title: Cancel
Control.p: Click Cancel to close the dialog and reset the process entirely.

Control.Name: lvItems
Control.Title: New Project
Control.p: Creates a new Keyman Keyboard, LDML Keyboard, or a Wordlist Lexical Model, or by importing from another source. Details are written on individual icons; clicking on them shows a detailed explanation of each keyboard project.

Control.Name: cmdOK
Control.Title: OK with the Selected Project
Control.p: Once decided on a project to create, click OK will take you to the next step.

Control.Name: cmdCancel
Control.Title: Cancel Project Creation
Control.p: Cancels creating a project.
